Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The Impact of Infrastructural Stress on Civil Society Participation in Post-Disaster Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Events like earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis, and floods are known to have important effects on both natural and social landscapes, but less discussed is the impact that natural disasters have on civil society. The proposed research seeks to examine how the 2017 hurricanes Irma and Maria might impact civil social behavior in Puerto Rico. These historic storms are certain to mark a turning point, not only for the massive damage they have caused to the island's infrastructure, but also for the extended state of emergency that was produced when millions of Puerto Ricans remained without electricity, water, and basic services for numerous weeks. Hurricane Maria has already created the largest black out in US history, it has caused greater infrastructural damage than Katrina, and is poised to completely transform the island of Puerto Rico and its political future. This project takes advantage of this unique state of infrastructural stress to ask how the storm, and its recovery process, will shape civil society behavior in years to come. In addition, the project would strengthen collaboration among scientists in the mainland U.S. and Puerto Rico, broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences, and train undergraduate and graduate students in methods of scientifically-grounded and empirical data collection.

This RAPID award supports the collection of critical but ephemeral data in Puerto Rico concerning the role that stresses on infrastructure play on civil society participation in post-disaster contexts. Dr. Yarimar Bonilla of Rutgers University explores how Puerto Rico's state of emergency, and the accompanying paralysis of basic physical infrastructure following Hurricanes Irma and Maria, have shaped sociopolitical behaviors. The study will use baseline data gathered in 2016 with over one thousand participants across five different regional sites in Puerto Rico. For this project researchers from the University of Puerto Rico, under the supervision of the PI, will contact participants from the previously conducted study to interview them about how they have experienced the storm and the recovery process. Investigators will assess how the state of emergency might have jostled pre-existing political beliefs, particularly how it might impact the desire (or not) for statehood. The results of this study will help offer a complex portrait of how the effects of climatic events are conditioned by pre-existing forms of governance and will help illuminate how natural disasters can transform political and social terrains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In January of 2018 I was granted an NSF RAPID award to investigate how the experiences of Hurricane Irma and Maria (and the recovery process that followed) might impact political attitudes in Puerto Rico. My goal was to examine how this disaster and its aftermath might impact Puerto Rican?s political attitudes and influence political behavior in years to come.

My goal was to contact participants from my previous study on political beliefs in the era of Puerto Rico's financial crisis. Working with undergraduate researchers from the University of Puerto Rico I developped an interview guide with questions such as: What material damage did they suffer after Maria, what aid did they receive, and from whom? How did they adapt to life without electricity or running water? How did they navigate the shortages of food, bottled water, gasoline, and basic supplies? How did the storm impact their employment, their educational aspirations, and their visions for the future? Did they or their family members decide to migrate as a result of the storms? How did they perceive the efforts of the local government, federal agencies, private companies, and non-governmental organizations? 

My hipothesis was that the storm would jostle deeply engrained political attitudes and lead local residents to question otherwise naturalized political scripts and beliefs.

As proposed, I travelled to Puerto Rico in Fall of 2017 to organize the research team, develop questionnaires, and train the research team. Between November 2017 and May 2018 the research team carried out structured interviews with nearly 200 study participants. I returned to Puerto Rico in Summer of 2018 and worked with the team on organizing, transcribing and coding the data, in addition to carrying out my own in depth, open-ended interviews. 

The preliminary results of the data gathered suggest that hurricane Maria did not jostle political attitudes in the sense of changing individual political beliefs. Instead, we found that residents interpreted the events that followed their storm through their previously held ideas. That is, pre-existing political beliefs operated as a prism through which recovery efforts were interpreted. For example, study participants who had previously reported support for Puerto Rican independence tended to see the shortcomings of the recovery as evidence for the need for greater political sovereignty, often suggesting that lifting the Jones Act (which constraints international relations) and/or developping better relations with Caribbean neighbors would improve Puerto Rico's ability to bounce back from environmental disasters. By contrast, those who supported statehood before the storm were similarly discontent with the recovery efforts, but felt that the outcomes would be different if Puerto Rico was an incorporated state (rather than an unincorporated territory). They tended to think that greater sovereignty would not have aided Puerto Rico's outcomes.

This short-term project will be intergrated into the PI's larger book manuscript which examines the relationship between Puerto Rico and the United States. Ultimately, this project can help us develop new ways of imagining what recovery might look like. The results from this study suggests that current residents in Puerto Rico are concerned not just with the immediacy of recovering from the storm, but with the deeper historical roots of their current predicament. By looking at the role between environmental disasters and the larger political and social terrains, this project asks: how can we develop visions of recovery that do not seek to simply re-establish a previous state of inequity but which actually offer substantive forms of transformation and redress? That is, if we understand disasters to have deep colonial histories, how then can we then formulate visions of repair that take those longer histories into account?
